item.description: See below for resources associated with the coding workshops from SIPPS 2022. For materials from other years and/or workshop series, follow this link. Week 1: Setting up your R environment Before the workshop: download these files: data file, RMarkdown file, R Project file After the workshop: RMarkdown file (with answers) Note: If you have trouble knitting your Rmd file, find the code chunk where you load in a set of packages (using the library() function), and remove the text eval = False.

item.description: See below for resources associated with the advanced-track coding workshops from SIPPS 2021. For materials from other years and/or workshop series, follow this link. item.title: About the SIPPS Program
item.description: → What is SIPPS? SIPPS is a 10-week summer program hosted within Columbia University’s Psychology department that aims to provide Columbia undergraduate and post-bac students with an immersive and practical introduction to psychological research. The SIPPS curriculum comprises two main components: (1) multiple weekly workshops, which involve hands-on training in practical research methods and tools (e.g., statistical analysis and coding, experimental design, and literature reviews); and (2) a mentored research experience, under the supervision of a graduate student or postdoctoral mentor.

item.title: Apply
item.description:
SIPPS 2023 applications are now closed! Decisions were sent out during the first few weeks of May. However, we’ve been notified that some of our emails are being mistakenly marked as spam. If you have not received a decision email, please check your spam folder, and reach out to sippscupsych@gmail.com if nothing is there.
Important Program Details SIPPS 2023 will run from June 12 to August 18.

item.title: Diversity Statement
item.description: The SIPPS team comprises a group of graduate students, post-docs, undergraduates, and faculty advisors who are committed to diversity and inclusion, in its broadest sense. We are scientists whose day-to-day research seeks to understand how people think, behave, and relate to one other and how differences in our experiences, both positive and adverse, affect our brain, relationships, and behavior. Our work encompasses and embraces the ideas of diversity and support.

item.title: Instructor Materials
item.description: Quick links for graduate students, postdocs, and staff in charge of putting on the SIPPS program. Please disregard if you are a participant in this program. Please contact Manasi if you are unable to access any of the links below. instructor schedule guidelines for instructors guidelines for mentored research experience mentor/mentee contract post-workshop exit survey (link coming soon)

item.title: Meet the SIPPS Team
item.description: SIPPS is a program developed & run primarily by graduate students, postdocs, and staff in Columbia’s Psychology Department. Core Team CJ Concepcion is a PhD student in the Couples Lab. She is interested in the physiological mechanisms that underlie cross-group interactions and how we can mitigate potential socioemotional and health consequences when such interactions are negative (i.e., experiencing discrimination). email Ana DiGiovanni is a PhD student in the Couples Lab.

item.title: Resources
item.description: On this page you will find an assortment of miscellaneous resources that you may find useful as a student interested in psychological research. Please note that all materials developed for specific workshop sessions will instead be found on the workshops page. Don’t hesitate to reach out to your mentor(s) and/or your instructors with specific questions about these resources. Summer Research Funding See this spreadsheet for a list of summer funding opportunities.

item.title: Schedule
item.description: SIPPS hosts three parallel workshop series, each with one session per week. See below for a detailed overview of all workshop topics and dates, and see the workshops page for materials associated with each session. Before each workshop, make sure to review any pre-workshop recordings & materials here! Professional Development Mondays, 11am-12pm Zoom links sent via email. Coding Wednesdays, 11am-12pm Zoom links sent via email.

item.title: SIPPS Mini-Conference
item.description:
Check out the presentations made by previous SIPPS participants during our end-of-summer conference! SIPPS 2022 Suppression of competing information during memory-guided attention Shelton Brister Mentor: Serra Favila
The impact of emotional valence on memory SooYeon Choi Mentors: Camille Gasser, John Thorp, & Wangjing Yu
How do beliefs about social regulation predict the quality and quantity of our social network?
